utterances: Yeah, you brought me to my next question.
How has the private investment sector received this?
They - in theory they like the plan because they do see the opportunity to make double-digit returns.
They do, I think, understand the reasoning behind the plan, in that Geithner can't get a trillion dollars from Congress, so this idea of leveraging it is a good idea.
They love the fact that the government is willing to indemnify them against losses.
But as we just talked about, they are terrified of being, you know, a year from now, being a poster child for greed…
Sure.
…and getting hauled up on Capitol Hill by lawmakers who want to rant and rave and then try to tax away their profits and demonize them.
Can I dunk back into your answer?
It's something - and forgive me, I don't necessarily have a head for business - how would someone make double-digit?
How would you have double-digit earnings on one of these assets you take on?
Well, to try to simplify it down - but let's say the bank made a loan for a dollar.
Okay.
But the person who borrowed that dollar can't repay it.
And we're going to have to oversimplify, but, you know, there's usually active secondary markets.
Because the truth is, banks will make loans and then they'll sell some of the loans to other banks.
And so there's actually like - it's almost like a secondary or stock market for, you know, loans being bought and sold among investors and everybody.
So you kind of have a price for what the value of that loan is.

Well, let's say the borrower is struggling to repay, people are doubtful they're going to repay, so that loan is basically - the effective market value or trade value is 30 cents on the dollar, because that's about what everyone suspects the bank will recover…
Dean…
…off the dollar.

And so basically, the government is going to come in and buy that for 30 cents and then the investor is going to come in and hold it for a couple of years and hope that they recover 45 cents, and that's a 50 percent return for them.

So Dean, as an aforth(ph), and as we look at the - what Timothy Geithner is presenting to us in the upcoming weeks, if you want our listeners to remember one thing or to concentrate on one thing, what would that be?

The one thing is that everyone is - every time he comes out with a plan or more details on the plan, everyone rants and screams about how it's an incomplete plan, there are not enough details, you know, they - he's not doing enough.
The reality is, if Tim Geithner worked in academia and had 10 years to think about the perfect solution.
He could come up with it, but, you know, life is moving on, and we got to get this economy back in gear.
And, yes, he is making it up as it goes along, and sometimes a - the best plan he can come up is better than the perfect plan you come up with in five years from now.
I touched up my hair last night, so...
I think the president understands the anger that is building.
I think he is very nervous about the prospect that at some point, the taxpayers, the citizens put so much pressure on their members in Congress to say no to any more taxpayer money.
And he is terrified that, suddenly, then the government will be powerless to try to pull this economy out of the ditch.
So I think the salesman in chief is going to go on TV tonight and try to make the case why, you know, we're in a mess, we don't like it.
It's kind of like your teenage son or daughter that goes to a party, you know, borrows the family car and goes to a party that you don't realize there might be a little alcohol.
And of course, you know, they get pulled and you're - you get the call from your 19-year-old son that he's in jail and.
You know what, he - at that point, you've just got to go deal with the problem.
You're going to be angry at your, you know, your teenager but you got to go bail him out and then go from there.
And it's the same here with Obama.
I mean, it's bad situation, taxpayers are paying a lot of money, but you got to deal with it if you want to get this economy moving again.
Dean Foust is Atlanta bureau chief for BusinessWeek.
He joined us from his office in New York City.
I know you were on deadline, so we really appreciate you taking the time to talk to us and explain so much.
Thanks so much, Dean.
Oh, my pleasure.
Thank you.
The war in Iraq is being debated in the House of Representatives today too.
This is the first full day the House has devoted to the war in Iraq since it began three years ago.
We're joined again by the Deputy Leader of House Republicans, Representative Roy Blunt of Missouri.
Congressman, welcome back to DAY TO DAY.
Alex, it's good to be with you again.
This resolution that you're debating today, the U.S.
will prevail in the War on Terror, who could vote against something like that?
Well, we'll see.
You know, I am the Whip in the House and we usually whip the critical votes that are before the House.

These votes that relate to war, that relate to the commitment of American men and women in the fighting field, we don't ask the members what they're going to do on that or even try to find out much about what the Democrats are going to do, and don't ask our members.
I think it's a very important resolution.
It's a very important time as this new government in Iraq is stood up.

As the fighting in Afghanistan transitions more to NATO forces, I think it's important that our commitment to see this effort through in both Afghanistan and Iraq is solid and can be depended on and we understand that the terrorists themselves have decided to make both of these locations a major battlefield in the fight that they're waging.
Well, Congressman, what the Democrats would like to do is amend this resolution, or have a chance to amend the resolution.
You won't let them do that.
They say that grouping Iraq and Afghanistan is misleading in some way, because while Afghanistan clearly was a war on terror, war that we fought, that is not established in the case of Iraq.
Well, you know, Alex, when our friends on the other side, if you don't have the facts on your side, you often argue procedure.
I'm told that in the Rules Committee that they were certainly given every opportunity to offer an alternative resolution and they didn't.
And I thought that Tony Blair said it very well the other morning at a press conference immediately after the world had found out about al-Zarqawi, when he said that...
The British Prime Minster.
...the terrorist themselves have decided to make Iraq a battleground.
They announced it is a battleground.
I think it's reasonable for us to recognize that it has become exactly that.
You spoke last week about the importance of maintaining the will of the American people.
Today the Department of Defense announced another unhappy milestone: 2,500 American servicemen and women now dead since the war began.
That kind of thing hurts what you're talking about.
Well, every - no question, every life is precious, every life given in defense of liberty or at the instruction of our government is precious and, you know, our hearts go out.
I think all of our hearts as Americans appreciate the sacrifice that individuals make and their families make.
But every one of those deaths affects the lives of family members forever and we need to be aware of that, and it's a sad milestone to pass.

Congressman, I mentioned in an earlier interview with Senator Durbin this piece in the LA Times today reporting that Republican strategists have concluded that politically the war in Iraq and the President's stance on it is actually going to help them in November before voters because the Democrats are uncertain about what to do.
What is your reaction to that?
I don't know the political evaluation of this.
I do know that as we approach the November election, that our friends, the Democrats, are eventually going to have to say what they're for.

They've thought, I believe, up until now they could win this election without having positions on the issues, and I don't think they believe that anymore and I don't think the American voters ever believed that.

So I think, you know, if their position is to raise the white flag and our position is to be resolute and fight our enemies in places where we have to fight them, I think the American people will look at those two alternatives and understand which one is the right one for America.
Republican Congressman Roy Blunt of Missouri.
Congressman, thank you again.
Good to be with you, Alex.
This is Talk of the Nation.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
For the remainder of the Democratic primary season, and most likely up until November, race will continue to figure at or near the top of the national political conversation.
Some of that discussion goes to policy, and issues on employment, affirmative action.

But a lot more centers on our personal experiences, who we see, who we talk to, or don't, how honest we are about resentments that have built up over decades about anger that, for many, is rooted in history.
Over the course of the next months, we'll talk about the issues and the policy differences.
I hope you can try.
And that is, do you think this is a problem that can begin to be reduced by dialogue, by process?
Or is this a problem that can only be reduced by attrition, if you will?
Oh yeah.
I heard somewhere that there's 64 different types of sounds you can create on the tabla, each stroke corresponding to a different sound.
And I only know about 20 of them I think (laughter).
But I've sort of assigned these very specific sounds on tabla to very specific sounds on the drum set in order to translate that material.
So you might have a phrase that's like (mimicking tabla beats) and then din has its own sound.
Dah has its own sound.
Geh has its own sound.
Neh has its own sound.
Different combinations of drums, different combinations of symbols that I feel, like, emulates those very specific sounds on tabla.
And it's really hard to practice in the beginning.
I have to start slow to work my way up to make this pretty awkward rhythm sound like something that's fluid on the drum set.
But after practicing a lot, it ends up sounding really, really cool.
(SOUNDBITE OF MOON HOOCH MUSIC)
There's this one element of Hindustani Indian classical music, and most of Indian music for that matter, it's called a tihai.
And basically what it is, it's a rhythm that's repeated three times.
And the last note of that rhythm lands on the downbeat of the next phrase.
So if you have a phrase like 1-2-3-4 (mimicking tabla beats), so that last tah is the next beat of the downbeat phrase.
So if I'm playing house groove, you know, (beat boxing) it's cool.
It's fun to experiment with.
(SOUNDBITE OF MOON HOOCH MUSIC)
James Muschler plays drums in the band Moon Hooch.
Their new album is called ""This Is Cave Music."" James Muschler, thanks so much.
Thank you, Arun.
Thank you so much.
(SOUNDBITE OF MOON HOOCH MUSIC)
If you're just joining us, it's ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR West.
I'm Arun Rath.
And I'm joined here in the studio by world music DJ Betto Arcos.
He's a frequent guest here on the program, and he's the host of ""Global Village"" on KPFK here in Los Angeles.
Betto, you have a very special treat for us today.
Some weeks back, you suggested we feature some Mexican Christmas music this weekend.
This week is not just you and me here chatting about CDs.
You brought us an entire band here in our cozy little studio.
Could you introduce us?
Yes.
I'd like to welcome to the studio the group Cambalache.
This is an east L.A.
ensemble that play the music from Veracruz called son jarocho.
This is a traditional roots music from the state of Veracruz in southern Mexico.
And please welcome to the studio Cesar Castro who plays the requinto, also known as a guitar Radisson.
He's also a vocalist and percussionist.
Xochi Flores on the zapateado, the foot tapping that you're going to hear.
She plays jarana.
She also does vocals.
Chuy Sandoval on the jarana.
He's also a singer.
And Juan Perez on the acoustic bass.
Thank you.
Thanks for having us.
